definition:
$f(n) \in O(g(n))$ if $\exists c, n_0 \ \forall n \geq n_0, \ f(n) \leq cg(n)$
It is sufficient to show that $\lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{f(n)}{g(n)}$ is finite

$f(n) \in \Omega(g(n))$ if $\exists c, n_0 \ \forall n \geq n_0, f(n) \geq c g(n)$
It is sufficient to show that $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{f(n)}{g(n)} > 0$

$f(n) \in \Theta(g(n))$ if $f(n) \in O(g(n)$ and $f(n) \in \Omega(g(n))$
It is sufficient to show that $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{f(n)}{g(n)} > 0$ and is finite

A matrix constructed similarly to a coefficient matrix but with information about constants in the linear system.

Formed by collecting all constants on the opposite side as the variables and appending them as a column vector on the right of the coefficient matrix.

The augmented matrix is commonly denoted $[A | b]$ with coefficient matrix $A$ and constant vector $b$.

Example:
$ \left| \begin{array}{c}
  2x + 8y + 4z = 2 \\
  2x + 5y + z = 5 \\
  4x + 10y - z = 1
\end{array} \right| $ has a augmented matrix $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c}
  2 & 8 & 4 & 2 \\
  2 & 5 & 1 & 5\\
  4 & 10 & -1 & 1
\end{array} \right]$

The matrix containing the coefficients of the variables in a particular linear system.

For the linear system $Ax = b$, $A$ is the coefficient matrix.

Note that:
1. Each column corresponds to the coefficients for exactly one variable
  a. Columns are generally ordered alphabetically by variable but
     are not required to do so
2. Each row corresponds to the coefficients for exactly one equation
3. Constants are excluded

Example:
$ \left| \begin{array}{c}
  2x + 8y + 4z = 2 \\
  2x + 5y + z = 5 \\
  4x + 10y - z = 1
\end{array} \right| $ has a coefficient matrix $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
  2 & 8 & 4 \\
  2 & 5 & 1 \\
  4 & 10 & -1
\end{array} \right]$

A number in $\mathbb{C}$.
A common form is $z = a + bi$ with $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$.

By euler's identity, $\exists \theta \in \mathbb{R}, \ z = |z|e^{i\theta}$
The modulus/norm of $z$ is $|z|$.
The phase of $z$ is $\theta$

A notation for vectors typically used in quantum physics.

Composed of the "bra" $\bra{\cdot}$ and the "ket" $\ket{\cdot}$

A "bra" and a "ket" may be combined to form a "braket", which is equivalent to the inner product: $\braket{\cdot | \cdot}$

The operations used to bring a matrix into reduced row-echelon form.

1. Divide a row by a nonzero scalar
2. Subtract a multiple of a row from another row
3. Swap two rows

The Hermitian operator combines the transpose and the element-wise complex conjugate on a vector.

Let $\ket{\psi} = \left[\begin{array}{c}
  a_0 \\
  \vdots \\
  a_n
\end{array}\right]$ where $a_0, \ldots, a_n \in \mathbb{C}$

$\bra{\psi} = (\ket{\psi})^\dagger = \left[\begin{array}{c}
  a_0^* \\
  \vdots \\
  a_n^*
\end{array}\right]^\top = \left[ a_0^* \ \cdots \ a_n^* \right]$

A vector $\vec{b} \in \mathbb{R}^n$ is a linear combination of $\vec{v}_1, \ldots, \vec{v}_m \in \mathbb{R}^n$ if  there exist scalars $x_1, \ldots, x_m$ such that $\vec{b} = x_1\vec{v_1} + \cdots + x_m\vec{v}_m$.

Note that a linear combination of columns in a matrix can be achieved with multiplication by a column vector on the right:
$\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
  | & & | \\
  \vec{v}_1 & \cdots & \vec{v}_m \\
  | & & |
\end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array}{c}
  x_1 \\
  \vdots \\
  x_m
\end{array} \right] = x_1\vec{v}_1 + \cdots + x_m\vec{v}_m$

Or of rows of a matrix by a row vector on the left:

$\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
  x_1 & \cdots & x_m
\end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
  \text{---} & \vec{v}_1 & \text{---} \\
  \ & \vdots & \ \\
  \text{---} & \vec{v}_m & \text{---} \\
\end{array} \right] = x_1\vec{v}_1 + \cdots + x_m\vec{v}_m$

A transformation $T$ from $\mathbb{R}^m$ to $\mathbb{R}^n$ is linear if and only if:

1. $\forall v, w \in \mathbb{R}^m, \quad T(\vec{v} + \vec{w}) = T(\vec{v} + \vec{w})$
2. $\forall \vec{v} \in \mathbb{R}^m \ \forall k \in \mathbb{R}, \quad T(k\vec{v}) = kT(\vec{v})$

Let $k \geq 1, b > 1, d \geq 0$ be constants that do not vary with $n$. Let $T(n)$ be a recurrence with base case $T(1) \in O(1)$ of the following form: $T(n) = k \cdot T(n/b) + O(n^d \log^w(n))$.

Note that we ignore all floors/ceilings and additions/subtractions to the $n/b$ argument on the RHS.

Then,

$T(n) \in \left\{\begin{array}{cc}
  O(n^d log^w(n)) & \text{if } k < b^d \\
  O(n^d\log^{w+1}(n)) & \text{if } k = b^d \\
  O(n^{\log_b(k)}) & \text{if } k > b^d
\end{array}\right.$

Further, the bounds are tight: the theorem also holds if all $O$s are replaced with $\Theta$s

The orthogonal projection of $\vec{x}$ onto line $L$ is $\text{proj}_L(\vec{x}) = \vec{x}^\|$.

It is the component of $\vec{x}$ parallel to $L$.

Note that, if line $L$ has a unit direction vector $\vec{u}$, then $\text{proj}_L(\vec{x}) = (\vec{u}\vec{u}^\top)\vec{x}$

The projection of $\vec{x}$ onto a line $L^\perp$ perpendicular to $L$ is $\vec{x}^\perp$

The rank of a matrix $A$ is the number of leading $1$s in $\text{rref}(A)$ and is denoted $\text{rank}(A)$

For an $n \times m$ matrix $A$, there is exactly one solution if $\text{rank}(A) = n = m$

A matrix is said to be in reduced row-echelon form if it satisfies the following conditions:

1. The first nonzero entry in any row is 1 (or the row is all 0)
2. If a column contains a leading 1, all other entries in the column are 0
3. The column index of leading 1s is strictly increasing

When using only elementary row operations, a matrix $A$ can be transformed to exactly one matrix $B$ in RREF. This unique solution is denoted $B = \text{rref}(A)$.

Examples:
$\left[ \begin{array}{cccc|c}
  0 & \boxed{1} & 0 & 0 & 1 \\
  0 & 0 & \boxed{1} & 0 & 7 \\
  0 & 0 & 0 & \boxed{1} & 3 \\
  0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
\end{array} \right]$ $\left[ \begin{array}{cccc|c}
  \boxed{1} & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
  0 & \boxed{1} & 0 & 2 & 0 \\
  0 & 0 & \boxed{1} & 3 & 0 \\
  0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \boxed{1} \\
\end{array} \right]$ $\left[ \begin{array}{ccccc}
  0 & \boxed{1} & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
  0 & 0 & \boxed{1} & 3 & 0 \\
  0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \boxed{1} \\
  0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
\end{array} \right]$

Like reduced row echelon form (rref), but only requiring that:

1. Pivots are non-zero
2. Entries below pivots are 0 (above can be anything)
3. Pivots follow the step pattern (described in rref)

A set $V$ with vector addition and scalar multiplication.

The following axioms must be satisfied:
1. Closed under addition.
2. Closed under scalar multiplication.
3. Addition is associative.
4. Addition is commutative.
5. There is an additive identity. $\exists 0_V \ \forall v \in V, \quad v + 0_V = 0_V + v = v$
6. Scalar multiplication is "associative": $\forall a, b \in \mathbb{R} \ \forall v \in V, \quad a(bv) = (ab)v$
7. $\forall v \in V, \quad 0v = 0_V$
8. $\forall v \in V, \quad 1v = v$
9. Scalar multiplication distributes over any addition:
  a. $\forall v, w \in V \ \forall \lambda \in \mathbb{R}, \quad \lambda (v + w) = \lambda v + \lambda w$
  b. $\forall v \in V \ \forall a, b \in \mathbb{R}, \quad (a + b)v = av + bv$
